_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The following information provided describes the executive summary for Americold Grand Chute Wisconsin risk management release prevention program to comply with the requirements of the EPA's 40 CFR Part 68.155- Executive Summary.  The RMP release prevention program for this facility is in conjunction with the OSHA 1910.119 process safety management program.  The hazard assessment for this process identifies potential off site consequences related to an accidental release of the chemical, anhydrous ammonia that is contained in the process.  A program management system is also in place at the facility that details the lines of authority for overall responsibility and maintenance of the release prevention program. 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE PREPAREDNESS

The AmeriCold Grand Chute, Wisconsin (Plant #2321) facility abides by the emergency procedures of OSHA 1910.38 emergency action plan. However this process is covered by hazwoper 1910.120 in the event of a chemical accident that requires emergency response.  The emergency response plan is coordinated with Outagamie County hazmat and the Wisconsin Emergency Management.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives: 



To save lives.

To minimize off site impacts and avoid injuries.

To protect the environment.

To minimize property damage.



AmeriCold maintains a (safety) committee and has employees designated as coordinators for the facility emergency action plan.   The Facility Service Manager and Plant Manager are responsible for the process safety and the emergency planning for off site consequences that are primary objectives of the risk management program. The emergency plan includes the instructions for notifications, safe evacuation and mitigation procedures to handle small releases.  To respond effectively in emergency situations involving a chemical release, employee responders are on call 24/7.  The emergency plan is reviewed

and updated when necessary and at least annually.  This Plan is in place to ensure the safety of the employees, the neighboring community, the environment and to sustain compliance with regulatory requirements to provide a work place that is safe.



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The AmeriCold Grand Chute facility is a public refrigerated warehouse SIC 4222 that stores and distributes a variety of food products for its customers. The refrigeration process, consisting of piping, valves, vessels, air units and compressor equipment utilizes anhydrous ammonia, a natural refrigerant for the industrial refrigeration system. Changes in pressure through the refrigeration cycle relate directly to changes in temperature of the refrigerant. For example, lowering the pressure of a refrigerant lowers its temperature. Low pressure, (cold) The ammonia refrigerant absorb heat through storage room air units.  Removal of the heat from the room provides the refrigeration affect.  Removal of ambient heat from products in turn reduces the spoilage and allows for extended storage of food products.

Anhydrous ammonia (CAS #766-41-7) Refrigerant grade, pure anhydrous ammonia is the chemical in the process.  In low concentrations ammonia is easily detectable and has a pungent odor that makes it ideal as a refrigerant because of this self alarming characteristic. 

The ammonia inventory at the Americold Grand Chute facility is above the Threshold Planning Quantity of 10,000 lbs.  Ammonia is listed and reportable as an extremely hazardous substances, EHS.  Due to the volume of ammonia in the process this facility, compliance is required under the the clean air act section CAA112r, RMP- Accidental Release Prevention Program, and OSHA 1910.119 PSM program three and section 302, 304, 311, 312 of the emergency planning community right to know act-EPCRA.  



CHEMICAL SPECIFIC AMMONIA RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



To assure safety, this process is maintained in ac

cordance with industry standards and best practices, including Americold corporate policies and procedures that are followed.  Americold Grand Chute adheres to the guidelines of the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR).  The standards and guidelines include the following but are not limited to:



IIAR Ammonia Data Book                                                                                                       IIAR Bulletin 107, "Suggested Safety and Operating Procedures When Making Ammonia Refrigeration Tie-ins"

IIAR Bulletin 109, "Minimum Safety Criteria for a Safe Ammonia Refrigeration System"

IIAR Bulletin R1, "A Guide to Good Practices for the Operation of an Ammonia Refrigeration System"



In conjunction with the RMP release prevention program, the OSHA 1910.119 PSM program is adopted as the culture in which this facility manages its compliance for the program elements of the EPA Risk Management Program.  

The release prevention program integrates the elements of process safety management that includes, employee participation, process safety information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, training, contractor qualifications, pre start up review, mechanical integrity, hot work, management of change, incident investigation, emergency planning, compliance audits.  This process has no trade secrets.  Of these elements mechanical integrity inspections and routine preventive maintenance procedures are on scheduled intervals to prevent process equipment deviations that could potentially result in an accidental release of ammonia.  Recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices are adhered to and followed to maintain the process equipment in safe operating condition.  

The process hazard analysis (PHA) study aimed at identifying process hazards and solutions for preventing potential releases, injury and environmental damage.  The study focused on improvements that help sustain a safer operation of the process

at this facility.  PHA recommendations receive careful consideration, especially when improved safety for the process is achievable.  Every effort is given by the PHA team to identify reasonable solutions and address all recommendations in an expeditious fashion. 



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There has been one release of ammonia at this facility reported to the National Response Center, state and local jurisdiction in the last 5 years that met the RMP reportable release criteria.  An evacuation of employees to an off site shelter was the criteria meeting the reportable event.  No injuries, deaths, or serious damage, or environmental impacts resulted from the accident.  



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The AmeriCold Grand Chute facility has an Emergency Action Plan in place according to the requirements of 1910.38 along with a fire prevention plan.  Emergency response for the facility is coordinated with Outagamie County Hazmat, and the Grand Chute Fire Department. The facility has trained employee responders to assist the local fire department and hazmat team during an emergency.  The refrigeration employees on staff received hazmat technician training for emergency response.  The hazmat technician employees receive 8 hour refresher training on an annual basis.  Emergency response team members receive occupational screening, medical evaluations, and are fit tested for the proper use of respiratory protection.  



The facility conducts annual evacuation drills to ensure all employees understand the emergency evacuation, and shelter in place procedures for different emergencies that can occur.  In addition, the Grand Chute Fire Department tours the facility annually for compliance with jurisdictional fire safety requirements.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

During the review of the Process Safety Management program at this facility, the Process Hazard Analysis study generated recommendations and measures to improve safety at the AmeriCold Grand Chute facilit

y located at 2005 W. Nordale Dr.  PHA findings that become action items that are entered into a schedule to address in a timely fashion.  Upgrades to the process that are targeted as improvement projects are listed below. New ammonia detection system through out the facility with alarms and interlocking safety systems to shut off ammonia feed. Upgraded emergency ventilation and emergency controls.  Safety relief valve and header system replacement.  Process piping changes and removal of obsolete equipment in the Nordale machinery room.
